text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with shrimp Fra Diavolo that's
right we're making what translates to
shrimp brother devil but you have to
admit is a pretty cool name and not only
is this what I think an incredibly
delicious shrimp recipe it's also
another test using the new editing
software and I'm only mentioning that in
case you notice any weirdness on the
audio or the video but anyway tech
disclaimers aside let's start this
incredibly delicious southern Italian
recipe and to do that we're gonna start
with a pound of shrimp and the size I'm
using there's about 22 a pound you're
gonna want a decent size shrimp because
we are going to sear these on very high
heats and these have been peeled and
deveined and most importantly they're
completely dry okay there's an old
Italian saying that basically translates
to if your shrimp aren't dry your fra
diavolo won't be fly so drain them very
thoroughly and blot them with some paper
towels and then we're going to season
those up a little bit and of course I
get anything named after the devil we
need some hot pepper so I'm going to put
in a whole bunch of red chili flakes and
then I'm going to cheat a little bit and
add a second kind of chili flake which
is the Aleppo pepper chili flake but you
know I love so a little bit of that
we're also going to want to add some
salt and some olive oil I will go ahead
and give that a mix with the spatula and
the reason we're going to coat these
enoy allow is because we're going to
sear these in a very hot pan and I think
it actually works better having the
olive oil on the shrimp then actually
heating it in the pan first okay so what
we'll do after that's mixed is pop that
in the fridge while we preheat our pan
so we're going to put down a heavy
skillet on the highest heat possible and
we're going to let that get hot very
very hot and how we're going to test
it's ready for the shrimp do you put in
a couple drips of water the water
doesn't evaporate let me check it out
the water looks like mercury so I'm not
sure how that's possible probably has
something to do with science but
regardless that's how hot you need to
get this at that point we're going to go
ahead and take our shrimp out of the
fridge and begin to sear it and for a
pan this size you should be able to get
the entire pound in there in one layer
and that's very very key here the shrimp
must be seared in a single layer in a
single layer in a single layer in a
single layer so do not pile these on top
of each other and because that pan was
smoking hot but dry
and the oil is actually on the shrimp
we're going to get a really really
beautiful sear so we're only going to
sear that first I two minutes or until
it's nicely browned like that and then
once all those have been turned we're
only going to give that other side one
minute
at which point we'll turn off the heat
and remove the shrimp tool bowl and no
those are not cooked go away but that's
what we want okay we're going to finish
these in the sauce at the end of the
recipe so just go ahead and reserve
those in a bowl while we start our sauce
so let's go ahead and put our heat back
on to medium and throw in some sliced
onions along with the big pinch of salt
and we'll go ahead and cook those on
medium until they just start to turn
translucent and get a little bit golden
and by the way do not wipe that pan out
after you do the shrimp all right all
those brown bits you see are just chili
flakes and little remnants from the
shrimp that caramelized onto the pan and
we totally want that stuff okay so we'll
cook those onions for a few minutes
stirring until they kind of soften up
and like I said get a little bit golden
brown at that point we're going to add a
nice big pinch of dry oregano and some
minced garlic and we'll stir that in and
we're just going to cook that about a
minute just to kind of take the raw edge
off that garlic and then we're going to
go ahead and de glaze with a nice big
glass of white wine and please use
something nice the old cliche is don't
use anything in the pan that you
wouldn't drink and that really is a
great tip unless of course you enjoy
drinking horrible cheap wine then don't
use that tip and get something nice but
basically any bottle of white table wine
should work and of course that wine is
going to deglaze the bottom and at this
point we can raise our heat up to high
because we want to bring this up to a
simmer and as soon as that wine starts
boiling we will go ahead and add our
tomato and it should come as a shock to
no one that I'm using some crushed San
Marzano tomatoes and seriously you need
to have some of those in your pantry
okay but anyway I'll remind you about
that on the post so we're going to stir
in some tomato of course we've switched
to the completely normally sized wooden
spoon
the official utensil of all Italian
tomato sauces and what we'll do as soon
as that tomatoes start simmering we'll
lower the heat to medium low and we'll
simply cook the sauce for about ten
minutes or until all those flavors meld
together and the mixture reduces and
thicken slightly so
guess to say about 10 to 15 minutes but
you decide you are the boss of your
brother devil sauce but anyway I went
ahead and simmered mine for about 10
minutes on medium low stirring
occasionally until it looked like this
and at that point we're ready for the
final phase of this recipe which is to
simply reheat the shrimp in the sauce so
let's go ahead and transfer our shrimp
back into the pan along with any
accumulated juices and have our
throwaway accumulated juices and we'll
go ahead and stir that shrimp in making
sure it's all nicely settled down into
that sauce and then all we need to do is
basically wait for that shrimp to heat
through which because we've seared our
shrimp ahead of time is only going to
take a few minutes and I really can't
give you specific times but you'll test
by checking one or two or three or four
to make sure they're heated through okay
and once those shrimp are heated through
we're basically done except we are going
to finish with some fresh herb so I'm
gonna throw in some freshly chopped to
tell you parsley and some sliced basil
leaves and we'll go ahead and stir that
in and at that point we can turn off the
heat and serve but not before we taste
for seasoning okay so give this a little
taste for salt it should be plenty spicy
enough but if it isn't you can add some
more chili flakes or a little bit of
kind if you're having withdrawal
symptoms and that shrimp Fra Diavolo is
done now generally this is served on
pasta some kind of angel hair or
linguine but you know me generally I
don't like to do is generally done so I
actually went etouffee on this thing and
served it over rice which is my personal
favorite and that my friends is one
spectacularly delicious spicy shrimp
dish
it's a little bit sweet it's a little
bit hot it's very aromatic all right
little bit of garlic a little bit of
herb in the background just a really
beautiful combination of flavors and
because we gave that shrimp a quick sear
and then just gently reheat it at the
end for a few minutes your shrimp should
be moist and very tender so anyway there
you go a very easy and incredibly
delicious shrimp dish and I think I
actually did another fairly successful
test of the new video editing software
which is premiere by the way if you have
any tips send them along but anyway old
dogs learning new tricks aside I really
do hope you give this a try
so head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always
enjoy
